title: Strict comparison in reduced group $C^*$-algebras

sections.text:
#### Abstract

We prove that for every $n \geq 2$, the reduced group $C^{*}$-algebras of the countable free groups $C_{r}^{*}\left(\mathbb{F}_{n}\right)$ have strict comparison. Our method works in a general setting: for $G$ in a large family of non-amenable groups, including hyperbolic groups, free products, mapping class groups, right-angled Artin groups etc., we have $C_{r}^{*}(G)$ have strict comparison. This work also has several applications in the theory of $C^{*}$-algebras including: resolving Leonel Robert's selflessness problem for $C_{r}^{*}(G)$; uniqueness of embeddings of the Jiang-Su algebra $\mathcal{Z}$ up to approximate unitary equivalence into $C_{r}^{*}(G)$; full computations of the Cuntz semigroup of $C_{r}^{*}(G)$ and future directions in the $C^{*}$-classification program.

## In memory of Dr. S. Balachander.
## 1. InTRODUCTION

1.1. Strict comparison. The subspaces of a finite dimensional Hilbert space $\mathcal{H}$ can be compared and classified by their dimension; algebraically, the dimension of a subspace $\mathcal{K} \subset \mathcal{H}$ is the trace of the orthogonal projection onto $\mathcal{K}$. For matrices $x, y$ one has the following natural notion of comparison, that is $x \precsim y$ if $x=r y s$ for some matrices $r, s$. It turns out here that the rank is what precisely implements this comparison, that is $\operatorname{rank}(x) \leq \operatorname{rank}(y)$ if and only if $x \precsim y$. Murray and von Neumann studied this comparison quite effectively in a broad setting of bounded operators on Hilbert spaces, in what are today called von Neumann algebras. In a broad class of von Neumann algebras known as $\mathrm{II}_{1}$ factors, they were able to establish a comparison theorem, showing that the lattice of projections under the above subequivalence is determined exactly by the unique finite trace [47]. Notably, in this context the trace takes on continuous values.

Such a comparison property allows for an algebraic perspective that is useful in operator algebras. Naturally one would want an analogue of the above Murray von Neumann comparison theorem in $C^{*}$-algebras. However, the behavior of $C^{*}$-algebras is very different as evidenced, for instance, by the typical lack of projections. Hence, an analogue of this property is not only subtle to define for all unital simple $C^{*}$-algebras but also will not hold automatically in all situations like in the setting of $\mathrm{II}_{1}$ factors. The appropriate analogue here is called strict comparison, initially considered by Blackadar [10]. This can be rephrased in a much more algebraic manner in terms of a certain notion of order-completeness (almost unperforation) of the important invariant called the Cuntz semigroup (see [57], and for instance, [27] or paragraph 3.4 of [3] for more details).

Let $A$ be a $C^{*}$-algebra and let $\mathbb{K}$ denote the compact operators on $\ell^{2}$. If $a, b \in(A \otimes \mathbb{K})_{+}$are positive elements, we say that $a \precsim b$ (Cuntz subequivalent) if there are $v_{n} \in A \otimes \mathbb{K}$ such that $v_{n}^{*} b v_{n} \rightarrow a$. If $a \precsim b$ and $b \precsim a$, we say that $a \sim b$. For $C^{*}$-algebras sometimes their behavior only becomes apparent at higher matrix levels, for instance the Bott projection which can only be seen in the $A \otimes \mathbb{M}_{2}(\mathbb{C})$ ). This is why stabilization with the compacts is necessary. Now given $\tau$ a trace on $A$, there is a canonical extension of $\tau$ on $A$ to $(A \otimes \mathbb{K})_{+}$(denoted by $\tau$ again). The dimension function here with respect to $\tau$ is defined on $(A \otimes \mathbb{K})_{+}$by $d_{\tau}(a):=\lim _{u} \tau\left(a^{\frac{1}{u}}\right)$ (note that for positive operators in matrices, $d_{\tau}$ precisely gives the rank of the operator). If $a, b \in(A \otimes \mathbb{K})_{+}$satisfy $a \precsim b$, then $d_{\tau}(a) \leq d_{\tau}(b)$. A unital, simple, exact $C^{*}$-algebra $A$ with unique trace $\tau$ has strict comparison

if whenever $a, b \in(A \otimes \mathbb{K})_{+}$are such that $d_{\tau}(a)<d_{\tau}(b)$, then $a \precsim b$. Note that all $C^{*}$-algebras considered in the main results of our paper will be unital, simple, exact and with unique trace, so that the above definition will suffice. In full generality, the definition will involve the space of quasitraces and is more subtle.

Despite being such a fundamental and natural property of a $C^{*}$-algebra, proving strict comparison is difficult and has far-reaching applications (please see subsection 1.3 where several applications arising from our present work are described). Strict comparison occupies an important place as a hypothesis in Elliott's important classification program, which seeks to classify simple, nuclear $C^{*}$-algebras by $K$-theoretical and tracial data. This program has seen immense success in recent times and has resulted in a substantial body of work due to several mathematicians (see for instance $[12,13,30,31,65,67])$. Note also the influential Toms-Winter conjecture predicts that three regularity properties of very different natures, namely topological (finite nuclear dimension), functional analytic ( $\mathcal{Z}$-stability), and algebraic (strict comparison), are equivalent for a separable, unital, simple, non-elementary, nuclear $C^{*}$-algebra $A$.
1.2. Context and main results. A prototypical example of a reduced group $C^{*}$-algebra is the one arising from the countable free group $\mathbb{F}_{2}$. The study of this $C^{*}$-algebra has been extremely important for opening up several deep insights in the subject. Some examples of this include the following fundamental results: unique trace and simplicity [52] (see also the major works [35,39] which were inspired by Powers' insights), lacking non-trivial projections [50], $K$-theory computations [50], and showing stable rank 1 [22] in the sense of Rieffel [54]. Despite these important developments, the fundamental question of proving strict comparison for $C_{r}^{*}\left(\mathbb{F}_{2}\right)$ has evaded experts. Within the community, it has been a widely-known open problem with initial motivation stemming from the work of Dykema-Rørdam in 1998 ( $[24,25]$, see also [55, Proposition 6.3.2]), which addresses comparison in $C_{r}^{*}\left(\mathbb{F}_{\infty}\right)$. Note that the ideas behind the proof for strict comparison for $C_{r}^{*}\left(\mathbb{F}_{\infty}\right)$ cannot be readily used to prove this result for $C_{r}^{*}\left(\mathbb{F}_{2}\right)$. For instance, the proof there uses the ability to find freely independent elements from any finite subsets, up to norm perturbations, which holds inside $C_{r}^{*}\left(\mathbb{F}_{\infty}\right)$. However such behavior is not clear at all to witness inside $C_{r}^{*}\left(\mathbb{F}_{2}\right)$. Strict comparison for $C_{r}^{*}\left(\mathbb{F}_{2}\right)$ has been explicitly stated as an open question in the work of Robert in 2012 [55] and in the recent substantial problem list in $C^{*}$-algebras [60], see Problems 86 and 88.

Robert in [56] asks a very interesting, more general question of selflessness for these $C^{*}$-algebras: the existence of a Haar unitary that is freely independent (in the reduced sense) from $C_{r}^{*}(G)$ viewed as the diagonal inclusion in its $C^{*}$-ultrapower. Interestingly, this property is well-studied and is of interest in the $\mathrm{II}_{1}$ factor context where it turns out that such freely independent unitaries can always be constructed, due to beautiful work of Popa from [51]. Robert obtained a crucial insight that this selflessness property in $C^{*}$-algebras implies strict comparison through a soft ultrapower argument. For natural reasons, this is of independent interest from a continuous model theory point of view.

Another key motivation for showing strict comparison is that it is crucial in fully computing the Cuntz semigroup, introduced by Cuntz in his fundamental investigation on the existence of traces on $C^{*}$-algebras [18]. Over several decades, Cuntz semigroup theory has evolved into a very mature field of research [27]. It has been a long-sought problem to obtain full computations of the Cuntz semigroup of reduced group $C^{*}$-algebras in a general sense and has been described in [27] as "may be out of reach". The problem of computing the Cuntz semigroup for $C_{r}^{*}\left(\mathbb{F}_{2}\right)$ is even explicitly stated as Problem 16.4 therein.

We settle all of the problems described above in this paper. Our first main result is the following:
Theorem A. For any $n \geq 2, C_{r}^{*}\left(\mathbb{F}_{n}\right)$ has strict comparison. In fact, $C_{r}^{*}\left(\mathbb{F}_{n}\right)$ is selfless in the sense of Robert [56].

Thanks to major developments $[45,57]$, we now know that for unital, separable, simple, unique trace, nuclear, infinite-dimensional $C^{*}$-algebras, strict comparison and $\mathcal{Z}$-stability are equivalent. Importantly, at the moment, outside the $\mathcal{Z}$-stable case there are only a few examples of strict comparison arising from groups, such as infinite reduced free products like $C_{r}^{*}\left(\mathbb{F}_{\infty}\right)$ ([55, Proposition 6.3.2]). With the next main result, we greatly expand the list of known examples. To motivate this, we need to discuss the following notion. We say a group $G$ has the rapid decay property if, for every finite generating set $X$, there exists a polynomial $P$ such that for every element $a \in \mathbb{C} G$ supported on $B_{X}(r),\left\|\lambda_{G}(a)\right\| \leq P(r)\|a\|_{2}$. The rapid decay property (see the survey [58]) was first proved by Haagerup for the free groups [33]. It was then generalized to Gromov hyperbolic groups [36,38], relatively hyperbolic groups with peripheral subgroups having rapid decay [58], cocompact lattices in $S L_{3}(\mathbb{R})$ or $S L_{3}(\mathbb{C})[14,42]$, mapping class groups of surfaces [7], large type Artin groups [15], heirarchically hyperbolic groups [5], and more. Rapid decay is extremely influential and has been used to prove several important problems, including the Novikov conjecture [16], the Baum-Connes conjecture [43], and others including [32]. Before we state our result, we will need to recall one more important and influential notion from geometric group theory [49]. A group is said to be acylindrically hyperbolic if it admits a non-elementary acylindrical action on a Gromov hyperbolic metric space. We direct the reader to [48] for context, examples, and references. We are now ready to state our next result:

Theorem B. Let $G$ be an arbitrary countable group that is acylindrically hyperbolic with trivial finite radical and, in addition, enjoys the rapid decay property. Then $C_{r}^{*}(G)$ has strict comparison. In fact, we have $C_{r}^{*}(G)$ is selfless in the sense of Robert [56].

Note that the trivial finite radical assumption in the above theorem is necessary due to the fact that these $C^{*}$-algebras will have unique trace as a consequence of being selfless (see also [11]). The following are some examples of groups (with an added trivial finite radical assumption) that fit into the above result (see $[20,48]$ ): non-elementary hyperbolic groups; non-elementary relatively hyperbolic groups relative to peripheral subgroups with the rapid decay property, which includes free products of groups with the rapid decay property; mapping class groups of compact orientable surfaces [8]; graph products of rapid decay groups over graphs without a splitting [46]; heirarchically hyperbolic groups [6]. In light of [42], it is very timely and interesting to ask if our main results hold in the setting of higher rank lattices, especially cocompact lattices in $S L_{3}(\mathbb{R})$. Our proof strategy has no bearing in this setting, and therefore we leave it as an important open question arising from our work. Notably, even stable rank 1 seems to be an open problem for reduced group $C^{*}$-algebras of higher rank lattices.

Importantly, also see Remark 3.9, which describes why the rapid decay assumption cannot be removed with our current approach. However, we point out that our result gives new examples of groups which do not have rapid decay property but whose reduced $C^{*}$-algebras are selfless. Indeed by Theorem A and Theorem 4.2 of [56], we have $C_{r}^{*}\left(\mathbb{F}_{2} * S L_{3}(\mathbb{Z})\right)$ is selfless, however $\mathbb{F}_{2} * S L_{3}(\mathbb{Z})$ does not have rapid decay.
1.3. Applications to classification and Cuntz semigroup theory. It is a very standard fact that every $\Pi_{1}$ factor contains a copy of the hyperfinite $\Pi_{1}$ factor $R$ uniquely up to pointwise approximate unitary equivalence. The most naïve analogue of this in $C^{*}$-algebras would be that every simple, unital, infinite-dimensional $C^{*}$-algebra contains the Jiang-Su algebra $\mathcal{Z}$ uniquely up to pointwise approximate unitary equivalence. Both existence and uniqueness problems for embeddings of $\mathcal{Z}$ tend to be difficult, see [60, Section 18]. It is known that there are simple, unital, infinite-dimensional $C^{*}$-algebras that do not contain $\mathcal{Z}$ [19]. It remains open if there is any unital $C^{*}$-algebra $A$ with two non-equivalent unital embedding of $\mathcal{Z}$. Our work yields the following concrete application. The result below follows from Proposition 6.3.1 in [55] and our Theorem B.

Note that for our examples, the uniqueness of the trace follows from the fact that the groups in consideration have trivial amenable radical and the unique quasitrace comes from exactness and Haagerup's famous quasitrace theorem [34]. Furthermore, stable rank one holds for all acylindrically hyperbolic groups [28]. Note also that the following result addresses problems 62 and 64 in [60]:

Theorem C. For any group $G$ in the class of groups covered in Theorem B, there is a unital embedding of the Jiang-Su algebra $\mathcal{Z} \rightarrow C_{r}^{*}(G)$, and this embedding is unique up to pointwise approximate unitary equivalence.

As explained in the beginning of the introduction, strict comparison is a crucial hypothesis that is used in classifying maps up to $K$-theoretic and tracial data in the nuclear setting. In the natural progression of the current landscape of classification, one expects new developments to emerge in the more general setting of non-nuclear $C^{*}$-algebras, wherein strict comparison will still naturally play a crucial role as a hypothesis for the co-domain for classifying maps between $C^{*}$-algebras up to the total invariant. Our results here will provide a wealth of interesting new and natural co-domains for this type of classification phenomena.

In [17], Coward-Elliott-Ivanescu gave a new picture of the Cuntz semigroup in terms of Hilbert modules; they showed that for $C^{*}$-algebras of stable rank one, the Cuntz semigroup encodes precisely the isomorphism classes of countably generated Hilbert modules, similarly to how the Murray-von Neumann semigroup encodes isomorphism classes of finitely generated projective modules. The theory of Cuntz semigroups is particularly well-developed for $C^{*}$-algebras of stable rank one [1]. An important notion in this context is pureness, which was introduced by Winter in his seminal study [66] of regularity properties for simple, nuclear $C^{*}$-algebras. Pureness can be thought of as $\mathcal{Z}$-stability at the level of the Cuntz semigroup, since in [2], it was shown that a $C^{*}$-algebra $A$ is pure if and only if its Cuntz semigroup $\mathrm{Cu}(A)$ tensorially absorbs $\mathrm{Cu}(\mathcal{Z})$. More recently, it was shown that pure $C^{*}$-algebras form a robust class [3], and as observed in [3, Example 5.14], if $G$ is an exact, infinite, $C^{*}$-simple group, then $C_{r}^{*}(G)$ has strict comparison if and only if $C_{r}^{*}(G)$ is pure. If $A$ is a unital, separable, simple, stably finite, pure $C^{*}$-algebra, then the Cuntz semigroup can be computed as $\mathrm{Cu}(A)=V(A) \sqcup \operatorname{LAff}(Q T(A))_{++}$, where $Q T(A)$ denotes the quasitracial states on $A$. If $A$ is exact, then $Q T(A)=T(A)$ by a famous result of Haagerup [34]. Thus, if G is an exact, infinite, $\mathrm{C}^{*}$-simple group such that $C_{r}^{*}(G)$ has strict comparison, then its Cuntz semigroup can be computed as $\mathrm{Cu}\left(C_{r}^{*}(G)\right)=V\left(C_{r}^{*}(G)\right) \sqcup[0, \infty]$ since such $C^{*}$-algebras have a unique trace [11]. Combined with our main results, this answers Problem 16.4 from [27] which asks to fully compute the Cuntz semigroup for $C_{r}^{*}\left(\mathbb{F}_{n}\right)$, which is a Cuntz semigroup version of Blackadar's fundamental comparison property [10] for projections in $C_{r}^{*}\left(\mathbb{F}_{n}\right)$.

Theorem D. The Cuntz semigroup of $C_{r}^{*}\left(\mathbb{F}_{2}\right)$ is $\mathbb{N} \sqcup[0, \infty]$ with the natural semigroup structure as in $\mathcal{Z}$.

Note that, our Theorem B can be used to fully compute the Cuntz semigroup for the vast family of acylindrically hyperbolic groups with trivial finite radical and with rapid decap property as described above. This partially settles the general problem in the paragraph before Problem 16.4 in [27], obtaining a full computation for many classes of $C^{*}$-simple groups. For examples of groups with stable rank one, see $[22,28,53]$. Note also that Theorem B additionally recovers with a new proof stable rank one for the families of groups in the statement (via [56]).
1.4. Functional analytic Tarski problem. We mention here that Theorem A in this paper will play a key role in the upcoming joint work [59] of the third author and C. Schafhauser, obtaining a negative resolution to Tarski problem on the first order theory of reduced free group $C^{*}$-algebras, showing that they are pairwise non elementarily equivalent. This is in sharp contrast to the positive

solution of Tarski's problem on the first order theory of free groups, obtained in the remarkable independent works of Sela and Kharlampovich-Myasnikov [40,61].
1.5. Comments. The inroad to prove strict comparison is to prove the more general free independence theorem in the norm ultrapower of the reduced group $C^{*}$ algebra, which is the selflessness property from [56]. Our inspiration for the argument to achieve this came from a recent very beautiful paper by Louder and Magee [44]. Curiously, our original approach to solving the problem of strict comparison was (motivated in a sense by the work of the third author [41]) to use strong convergence methods in random matrix theory, and this is what indirectly led us to [44]. Now, in order to prove this free independence theorem, one benefits by using the rapid decay property (see $[33,58]$ ), which allows one to control the operator norm of elements in the group ring in terms of the radius of the ball of support and the 2 -norm. A key next step is a quantitative analysis of the eventual faithfulness of certain tailored retraction maps that one constructs using the group structure; for instance, free product structure, or, more generally, an acylindrical action on a hyperbolic space. This is used to obtain a particularly strong existential inclusion of the group into the free product of itself with a copy of $\mathbb{Z}$. Piecing these ideas together allows one to push this inclusion to the level of the reduced group $C^{*}$-algebra, as needed.

A note to the reader. The proofs of these results split into a hands-on computational part (showing selflessness in our sense, see 3.1) and a soft $C^{*}$-algebra part (using rapid decay à la Louder-Magee, see Theorem 3.5). If the reader would like to just focus on understanding the proof of Theorem A, we direct them to a self contained approach via the combination of Proposition 3.2 and Theorem 3.5. The quantitative part of the proof of Theorem B is rather involved, but quite natural from a geometric point of view. Appendix A contains a quantitative version of a key theorem of Wenyuan Wang that is needed to prove our result B. This is quite technical and we recommend the interested reader to side by side refer to [68, Corollary 3.4].

# 2. Notation 

Let $\Gamma$ be a countable discrete group. If $Y$ is a generating set for $\Gamma$ then we denote by $B_{Y}(R)$ the elements of the $R$-ball around the identity in the Cayley graph of $\Gamma$ with the generating set $Y$. Let $\mathbb{C} \Gamma$ denote the complex group algebra associated to $\Gamma$. We equip $\mathbb{C} \Gamma$ with three separate norms. Let $x=\sum x_{g} g$, then

$$
\begin{aligned}
\|x\|_{1} & :=\sum_{g \in \Gamma}\left|x_{g}\right| \\
\|x\|_{2}^{2} & :=\sum_{g \in \Gamma}\left|x_{g}\right|^{2} \\
\|x\| & :=\sup \left\{\|x y\|_{2}: y \in \mathbb{C} \Gamma,\|y\|_{2} \leq 1\right\}
\end{aligned}
$$

We call these norms on $\mathbb{C} \Gamma$ the $\ell^{1}$-norm, the $\ell^{2}$-norm, and the operator norm respectively. As suggested by the definition of the operator norm, each element of $\mathbb{C} \Gamma$ can be viewed as a bounded operator on $\ell^{2}(\Gamma)$. We define the reduced group $C^{*}$-algebra $C_{r}^{*}(\Gamma)$ to be the operator norm closure of $\mathbb{C} \Gamma$ inside of $\mathbb{B}\left(\ell^{2}(\Gamma)\right)$.

A state on a unital $C^{*}$-algebra $A$ is a positive linear functional $\phi$ such that $\phi(1)=1$. We say a state $\phi$ is faithful if $\phi\left(x^{*} x\right)>0$ for any nonzero $x \in A$. We call $\phi$ a trace if $\phi(x y)=\phi(y x)$ for all $x, y \in A$. Let $A_{1}, A_{2} \subset(A, \phi)$ be subalgebras. We say that $A_{1}$ and $A_{2}$ are freely independent relative to $\phi$ if whenever $a_{k} \in A_{i_{k}}$ with $\phi\left(a_{k}\right)=0$ and $i_{k} \neq i_{k+1}$ for $1 \leq k \leq n$ then $\phi\left(a_{1} \cdots a_{n}\right)=0$. If $\left(B_{1}, \rho\right),\left(B_{2}, \rho\right)$ are unital $C^{*}$-algebras with faithful states, then there is a unital $C^{*}$-algebra with faithful state $(B, \rho)$ and embeddings $\pi_{i}:\left(B_{i}, \rho\right) \hookrightarrow(B, \rho)$ such that $\pi_{1}\left(B_{1}\right)$ and $\pi_{2}\left(B_{2}\right)$ are freely independent relative to $\rho$. We call $(B, \rho)$ the reduced free product of $\left(B_{1}, \rho_{1}\right)$ and $\left(B_{2}, \rho_{2}\right)$; we omit the states when they are clear from context (see $[4,63]$ ).

Let $\mathcal{U}$ be a free ultrafilter on the natural numbers. For a discrete group $\Gamma$ we denote by $\Gamma^{\mathcal{U}}$ the following quotient:

$$
\Gamma^{\mathcal{U}}:=\left(\prod_{N} \Gamma\right) / N_{\mathcal{U}}
$$

where $N_{\mathcal{U}}$ consists of all sequences which are eventually constant with respect to $\mathcal{U}$. More precisely, a sequence $\left(g_{n}\right)_{n} \in N$ if and only if there is $h \in \Gamma$ and $S \in \mathcal{U}$ such that $g_{n}=h$ for all $n \in S$. We call $\Gamma^{\mathcal{U}}$ an ultrapower of $\Gamma$. If $A$ is a $C^{*}$-algebra, we define $A^{\mathcal{U}}$ as

$$
A^{\mathcal{U}}:=\left\{\left(x_{n}\right)_{n}: x_{n} \in A, \sup _{n}\left\|x_{n}\right\|<\infty\right\} / I_{\mathcal{U}}
$$

where $I_{\mathcal{U}}$ consists of all norm-bounded sequences $\left(x_{n}\right)$ in $A$ with the following property: for all $\varepsilon>0$ there is $S \in \mathcal{U}$ such that for all $n \geq N,\left\|x_{n}\right\|<\varepsilon$. We call $A^{\mathcal{U}}$ an ultrapower of $A$.

# 3. Proof of MAIN RESULTS 

3.1. A new property for groups. The following is a quantitative strengthening of the definition of the mixed identity free (MIF) property for groups [37], and our terminology is motivated by [56].
Definition 3.1. We say a group with a finite generating set $(G, X)$ is selfless if there is a function $f: \mathbb{N} \rightarrow \mathbb{R}$ with $\liminf _{n} f(n)^{\frac{1}{n}}=1$ such that for all $n \geq 1$, there is an epimorphism $\phi_{n}: G *\langle a\rangle \rightarrow G$ such that $\left.\phi_{n}\right|_{G}=\operatorname{id}_{G}, \phi_{n}$ is injective on $B_{X \cup\{a\}}(n)$, and $\phi_{n}\left(B_{X \cup\{a\}}(n)\right) \subset B_{X}(f(n))$. Here, $a$ is a torsion-free generator so that $G *\langle a\rangle \cong G * \mathbb{Z}$.

The following is a particularly motivating example:
Proposition 3.2. If $(G, X)$ contains a torsion-free element and $(H, Y)$ is an infinite group, then $G * H$ is selfless. In particular, $\mathbb{F}_{n}$ is selfless for all $n \geq 2$.
Proof. Let $g \in G$ be torsion-free. Set $p=|g|_{X}$. For each $n$ let $h_{n} \in H$ be an element such that $\left|h_{n}\right|_{Y}>2 n$ and $\liminf _{n}\left|h_{n}\right| \frac{1}{Y}=1$. Define $\phi_{n}: G * H *\langle a\rangle \rightarrow G * H$ by $\left.\phi_{n}\right|_{G * H}=\operatorname{id}_{G * H}$ and $\phi_{n}(a)=h_{n} g h_{n}^{-1}$. It is clear that $\liminf _{n}\left|\phi_{n}(a)\right| \frac{1}{X \cup Y}=1$, and therefore

$$
\phi_{n}\left(B_{X \cup Y \cup\{a\}}(n)\right) \subset B_{X \cup Y}(f(n))
$$

for some function $f$ where $\liminf _{n} f(n)^{\frac{1}{n}}=1$.
It remains to show that $\phi_{n}$ is injective on $B_{X \cup Y \cup\{a\}}(n)$. It suffices to show that, if

$$
s_{1} t_{1} \cdots s_{m-1} t_{m-1} s_{m}=e
$$

where $s_{i} \in G * H$ are such that $\left|s_{i}\right|_{X \cup Y} \leq 2 n$ for all $1 \leq i \leq m$ and $s_{i} \neq e$ for all $1<i<m$, and $t_{i}=h_{n} g^{p_{i}} h_{n}^{-1}$ for some nonzero integers $p_{i}$, then $m=1$ and $s_{1}=e$.

Now, assume $m>2$. Write all $s_{i}$ in standard form for the free product $G * H$. Then all the words in $s_{i}$ from $H$ have word length (with respect to $Y$ ) at most $2 n$, while $\left|h_{n}\right|_{Y}>2 n$, so no full cancellation can happen between them. Thus, if all $s_{i}$ with $1<i<m$ have terms in $G$, then the standard form of $s_{1} t_{1} \cdots s_{m-1} t_{m-1} s_{m}$ is,

$$
h_{1}^{\prime} g^{p_{1}} h_{2,1}^{\prime} g_{2,1}^{\prime} h_{2,2}^{\prime} \cdots g_{2, k_{2}-1}^{\prime} h_{2, k_{2}}^{\prime} g^{p_{2}} \cdots h_{m-1, k_{m-1}}^{\prime} g^{p_{m-1}} h_{m}^{\prime}
$$

where all $h^{\prime}$ are non-identity elements of $H$ and all $g^{\prime}$ are non-identity elements of $G$. In particular, it is not the identity. Therefore, there is some $1<i<m$ s.t. $s_{i} \in H$. But as $s_{i} \neq e$ for $1<i<m$, we have $h_{n}^{-1} s_{i} h_{n}$ is a non-identity element of $H$ when $s_{i} \in H$, so examining the standard form again, we see that such terms $h_{n}^{-1} s_{i} h_{n}$ will appear in the standard form, again a contradiction. This shows $m \leq 2$. Now, if $m=2$, then $s_{1} t_{1} \cdots s_{m-1} t_{m-1} s_{m}=s_{1} t_{1} s_{2}$. Again, any $H$-term in the standard forms of either $s_{1}$ or $s_{2}$ cannot fully cancel with $h_{n}$ or $h_{n}^{-1}$. So, $g^{p_{1}}$ will appear in the standard form, which is a contradiction. Hence, $m=1$ and $s_{1}=e$.
3.2. A general family of selfless groups. We will prove here that all acylindrically hyperbolic groups with trivial finite radical are selfless. For this subsection, for background notation and preliminaries on acylindrically hyperbolic groups, please refer to the beautiful memoir [20], and also [48]. At the outset we wish to express our gratitude to the following two experts for their guidance. Firstly we sincerely thank D. Osin who first pointed out to us that our selflessness for free products (Proposition 3.2) will hold in the general setting of acylindrically hyperbolic groups. Secondly we are very grateful to W. Yang for kindly sharing with us his ideas towards a different approach. First we describe the outline for our proof:

Outline of proof. The key step in the proof is to use a hyperbolically embedded $\mathbb{F}_{2}$ subgroup to construct the sequence of elements going to infinity, which will implement selflessness. The fact that this embedding is a Lipschitz quasi-retract [20] is crucial to relate word length inside $\mathbb{F}_{2}$ and $G$. Then to check that these elements don't form a trivial word with a ball with a controlled cogrowth, we have to use a quantitative version of Wenyuan Yang's "admissible path lemma" in [68], and argue that any word yields a quasi-geodesic. The proof crucially uses both acylindricity and geometry of hyperbolic space. Roughly, it says that a concatenation of quasigeodesics which travels alternatively near contracting subsets and leaves them in an orthogonal way, is a quasigeodesic. The careful quantitative analysis of this argument which is needed for our proof is done in Appendix A.

Theorem 3.3. Let $G$ be an acylindrically hyperbolic group with trivial finite radical. Then $G$ is selfless.

Proof. Fix a finite generating set $S$ for $G$. Since $G$ is acylindrically hyperbolic and has trivial finite radical, by [20, Theorem 6.14], there is a hyperbolically embedded copy of $\mathbb{F}_{2}$ in $G$. Denote by $a, b$ the generators of $\mathbb{F}_{2}$. Since $\langle a\rangle$ is hyperbolically embedded in $\mathbb{F}_{2}$, by transitivity of hyperbolic embeddings [20, Proposition 4.35] we have that $\langle a\rangle$ is hyperbolically embedded in $G$. Therefore $\langle a\rangle$ is almost malnormal in $G$ [20, Proposition 4.33], implying that the maximal virtually cyclic subgroup containing $a$, namely $E(a)$, is equal to $\langle a\rangle$ (see [26] for details on virtually cyclic groups). By [20, Theorem 4.31], we have that this copy of $\mathbb{F}_{2}$, with word metric given by its generating set $\{a, b\}$, is a Lipschitz quasi-retract of $G$ with word metric given by $S$. Therefore there are constants $C, D$ such that whenever $g \in \mathbb{F}_{2},\left|g\right|_{\{a, b\}} \leq C|g|_{S}$ and $|g|_{S} \leq D|g|_{\{a, b\}}$. Since $a$ has infinite order, [48, Theorem 1.4] says that there is an acylindrical action of $G$ on a hyperbolic space $X$ such that $a$ is loxodromic.

Now consider the sequence $g_{n}=b^{n} a b^{-n}$. We note that each $g_{n}$ is loxodromic for the action $G \curvearrowright X$; moreover, each $g_{n}$ is primitive. Thus $E\left(g_{n}\right)=\left\langle g_{n}\right\rangle$ for all $n$. We note that for all $n \geq \frac{1}{2} C^{2} D$ and any $h \in B_{S}\left(\left|g_{n}\right|_{S}^{1 / 2}\right)$ (the $\left|g_{n}\right|_{S}^{1 / 2}$-ball around the identity in the Cayley graph of $G$ with the

generating set $S$ ), we have $h \notin E\left(g_{n}\right)$. Indeed, $\left|g_{n}\right|_{\{a, b\}}=2 n+1>C^{2} D$ which implies that either $h \notin \mathbb{F}_{2}$ or

$$
|h|_{\{a, b\}} \leq C|h|_{S} \leq C\left|g_{n}\right|_{S}^{1 / 2} \leq C \sqrt{D}\left|g_{n}\right|_{\{a, b\}}^{1 / 2}<\left|g_{n}\right|_{\{a, b\}}
$$

while clearly every element $g^{\prime} \in E\left(g_{n}\right)$ is an element of $\mathbb{F}_{2}$ with $\left|g^{\prime}\right|_{\{a, b\}} \geq\left|g_{n}\right|_{\{a, b\}}$.
Since all of the $g_{n}$ are conjugate, they all have equal stable length. Therefore we can apply Theorem A. 4 to get a degree 6 polynomial $P$ such that whenever $h_{1}, \ldots, h_{m} \in B_{S}\left(\left|g_{n}\right|_{S}^{1 / 2}\right)$ and $\left|k_{1}\right|, \ldots,\left|k_{m}\right| \geq P\left(\left|g_{n}\right|_{S}\right)$ we have $h_{1} g_{n}^{k_{1}} \cdots h_{m} g_{n}^{k_{m}} \neq e$. In particular, taking $g_{n}^{\prime}=g_{n}^{P\left(\left|g_{n}\right|_{S}\right)}$ we have $h_{1}\left(g_{n}^{\prime}\right)^{k_{1}} \cdots h_{m}\left(g_{n}^{\prime}\right)^{k_{m}} \neq e$ for any non-zero integers $k_{i}$. This, along with $\mathbb{F}_{2}$ being a Lipschitz quasi-retract of $G$, implies that there is a sequence $g_{n}^{\prime \prime} \in G$ with $\left|g_{n}^{\prime \prime}\right|_{S}=O\left(n^{12}\right)$ and a constant $N$ so that for any $n>N$, we have that any word $w=h_{1}\left(g_{n}^{\prime \prime}\right)^{n_{1}} h_{2}\left(g_{n}^{\prime \prime}\right)^{n_{2}} \cdots h_{k}\left(g_{n}^{\prime \prime}\right)^{n_{k}} h_{k+1} \neq e$ where $h_{i} \in B_{S}(n)$, concluding the proof.

# 3.3. Proving strict comparison for $C_{r}^{*}(G)$. 

Definition 3.4. Let $G \leq \Gamma$ be countable discrete groups. We say that $\Gamma$ is existentially $C^{*}$ -residually- $G$ (terminology motivated by [44]) if for all finite sets $S \subset \Gamma$ and $\varepsilon>0$, there is a homomorphism $\phi: \Gamma \rightarrow G$ such that $\left.\phi\right|_{G}=\operatorname{id}_{G}$ and for all $z \in \mathbb{C} \Gamma$ supported on $S$ with $\|z\|_{1}=1$, we have $\left\|\lambda_{G}(\phi(z))\right\| \leq\left\|\lambda_{\Gamma}(z)\right\|+\varepsilon$.

Theorem 3.5. Suppose $(G, X)$ is selfless and has rapid decay. Then $G *\langle a\rangle \cong G * \mathbb{Z}$ is existentially $C^{*}$-residually- $G$.

Proof. We follow the proof of [44, Theorem 1.6]. Set $Y=X \cup\{a\}$ to be our finite generating set of $\Gamma:=G * \mathbb{Z}$. Let $\varepsilon>0$ and let $S \subset \Gamma$ be a finite subset. Then there is some $R>0$ such that $S \subset B_{Y}(R)$. Let $S_{Y}(R) \subset \mathbb{C} \Gamma$ denote the elements supported on $B_{Y}(R)$ with $\ell^{1}$ norm equal to 1 . Using compactness of $S_{Y}(R)$ with respect to the $\ell^{1}$ norm, we find a finite $\frac{\varepsilon}{3}$-net $\left\{a_{i}\right\}_{i \in I}$ for $S_{Y}(R)$. It now suffices to prove the existence of a homomorphism $\phi: \Gamma \rightarrow G$ such that $\left.\phi\right|_{G}=\mathrm{id}_{G}$ and that, for all $i \in I$,

$$
\left\|\lambda_{G}\left(\phi\left(a_{i}\right)\right)\right\| \leq\left\|\lambda_{\Gamma}\left(a_{i}\right)\right\|+\frac{\varepsilon}{3}
$$

Since $G$ is selfless, we get a function $f: \mathbb{N} \rightarrow \mathbb{R}$ such that $\liminf _{n} f(n)^{\frac{1}{n}}=1$ and homomorphisms $\phi_{n}: \Gamma \rightarrow G$ which are onto, are identity on $G$, are injective on $B_{Y}(n)$, and such that $\phi_{n}\left(B_{Y}(n)\right) \subset$ $B_{X}(f(n))$. Using rapid decay of $G$ we get a polynomial $P$ such that $\left\|\lambda_{G}(a)\right\| \leq P(r)\|a\|_{2}$ for all $a$ supported on $B_{X}(r)$. Now, as $\liminf _{n} f(n)^{\frac{1}{n}}=1$, we may pick $m$ such that $P(f(2 m R))^{\frac{1}{2 m}}<1+\frac{\varepsilon}{3}$. Define $b_{i}=\phi_{2 m R}\left(a_{i}\right)$ for each $i \in I$.

Note that $\left\|\lambda_{\Gamma}\left(a_{i}\right)\right\|^{2 m}=\left\|\lambda_{\Gamma}\left(a_{i}^{*} a_{i}\right)^{m}\right\|$ and similarly $\left\|\lambda_{G}\left(b_{i}\right)\right\|^{2 m}=\left\|\lambda_{G}\left(b_{i}^{*} b_{i}\right)^{m}\right\|$. Since each $a_{i}$ is supported on $B_{Y}(R)$, each $\left(b_{i}^{*} b_{i}\right)^{m}$ is supported on $B_{X}(f(2 m R))$. Since $\phi_{2 m R}$ is injective on $B_{Y}(2 m R)$, we have that $\left\|\left(b_{i}^{*} b_{i}\right)^{m}\right\|_{2}=\left\|\left(a_{i}^{*} a_{i}\right)^{m}\right\|_{2}$. Therefore

$$
\begin{aligned}
\left\|\lambda_{G}\left(b_{i}\right)\right\|^{2 m} & =\left\|\lambda_{G}\left(b_{i}^{*} b_{i}\right)^{m}\right\| \\
& \leq P(f(2 m R))\left\|\left(b_{i}^{*} b_{i}\right)^{m}\right\|_{2} \\
& =P(f(2 m R))\left\|\left(a_{i}^{*} a_{i}\right)^{m}\right\|_{2} \\
& \leq P(f(2 m R))\left\|\lambda_{\Gamma}\left(a_{i}\right)\right\|^{2 m}
\end{aligned}
$$

Since we assumed that $\left\|a_{i}\right\|_{1}=1$, we conclude that

$$
\begin{aligned}
\left\|\lambda_{G}\left(b_{i}\right)\right\| & \leq P(f(2 m R))^{\frac{1}{2 m}}\left\|\lambda_{\Gamma}\left(a_{i}\right)\right\| \\
& \leq\left(1+\frac{\varepsilon}{3}\right)\left\|\lambda_{\Gamma}\left(a_{i}\right)\right\| \\
& \leq\left\|\lambda_{\Gamma}\left(a_{i}\right)\right\|+\frac{\varepsilon}{3}
\end{aligned}
$$

Remark 3.6. In the above proof, the injectivity of $\phi_{n}$ on the radius $n$ ball $B_{X \cup\{a\}}(n)$ is used only to obtain the equality $\left\|\left(b_{i}^{*} b_{i}\right)^{m}\right\|_{2}=\left\|\left(a_{i}^{*} a_{i}\right)^{m}\right\|_{2}$. If instead $\phi_{n}$ is $g(n)$-to-1 on the radius $n$ ball for some function $g: \mathbb{N} \rightarrow \mathbb{R}$ such that $\lim g(n)^{\frac{1}{n}}=1$, then by the Cauchy-Schwarz inequality we would still have $\left\|\left(b_{i}^{*} b_{i}\right)^{m}\right\|_{2} \leq \sqrt{g(2 m R)}\left\|\left(a_{i}^{*} a_{i}\right)^{m}\right\|_{2}$ and the rest of the proof would proceed as above. To summarize, in the definition of selfless, we can assert the weaker condition that $\phi_{n}$ is $g(n)$-to-1 for some subexponential function $g$. Note that in this setting, the group homomorphism $\phi=\left(\phi_{n}\right)_{\mathcal{U}}: G * \mathbb{Z} \rightarrow G^{\mathcal{U}}$ is no longer necessarily injective, which isn't a requirement anyway to prove Proposition 3.7. We suspect that this approach might also help resolve the question of strict comparison in broader generality.

Proposition 3.7. If $\Gamma$ is existentially $C^{*}$-residually- $G$, then for some free ultrafilter $\mathcal{U}$ on $\mathbb{N}$ there is a $*$-homomorphism $\phi: C_{r}^{*}(\Gamma) \rightarrow C_{r}^{*}(G)^{\mathcal{U}}$ such that $\phi \circ \iota=\Delta$ where $\iota$ is the inclusion of $C_{r}^{*}(G) \subset$ $C_{r}^{*}(\Gamma)$ arising from the group inclusion $G \leq \Gamma$ and $\Delta$ is the diagonal embedding $C_{r}^{*}(G) \subset C_{r}^{*}(G)^{\mathcal{U}}$.

Proof. Since $\Gamma$ is existentially $C^{*}$-residually- $G$, there are epimorphisms $\phi_{n}: \Gamma \rightarrow G$ which are identity on $G$ and such that for all $z \in \mathbb{C} \Gamma$ with $\|z\|_{1}=1$ we have

$$
\lim _{n \rightarrow \mathcal{U}}\left\|\lambda_{G}\left(\phi_{n}(z)\right)\right\| \leq\left\|\lambda_{\Gamma}(z)\right\|
$$

In other words, for all $z \in \mathbb{C} \Gamma$ with $\|z\|_{1}=1$ we have

$$
\left\|\left(\phi_{n}(z)\right)_{\mathcal{U}}\right\|_{C_{r}^{*}(G)^{\mathcal{U}}} \leq\|z\|_{C_{r}^{*}(\Gamma)}
$$

Since the map $\phi=\left(\phi_{n}\right)_{\mathcal{U}}$ is a homomorphism, we immediately get the previous inequality for all $z \in \mathbb{C} \Gamma$. Then the inequality implies that we can extend $\phi$ continuously to all of $C_{r}^{*}(\Gamma)$; thus, $\phi$ is the desired embedding.

Corollary 3.8. If $G * \mathbb{Z}$ is existentially $C^{*}$-residually- $G$, then $C_{r}^{*}(G)$ is selfless in the sense of [56]. In particular, $C_{r}^{*}(G)$ has strict comparison.

Proof. By [56, Proposition 5], it suffices to show that, for some free ultrafilter $\mathcal{U}$ on $\mathbb{N}$ there is an injective $*$-homomorphism $\phi$ from the reduced free product $C_{r}^{*}(G) * C_{r}^{*}(\mathbb{Z})$ to $C_{r}^{*}(G)^{\mathcal{U}}$ such that, composing with the canonical inclusion $C_{r}^{*}(G) \subset C_{r}^{*}(G) * C_{r}^{*}(\mathbb{Z})$, we obtain the diagonal embedding $C_{r}^{*}(G) \subset C_{r}^{*}(G)^{\mathcal{U}}$. In other words, we require an existential embedding of $C_{r}^{*}(G) * C_{r}^{*}(\mathbb{Z})$ in $C_{r}^{*}(G)^{\mathcal{U}}$. But this is precisely the content of Proposition 3.7.

Remark 3.9. In [23] and [28], the existence of sufficiently many free sub-semigroups of $G$ with a form of the rapid decay property, which they call the $\ell^{2}$-spectral radius property, is sufficient to show stable rank 1 of $C_{r}^{*}(G)$. In our setting, to show that $C_{r}^{*}(G)$ is selfless and therefore has strict comparison, we need an embedding of $C_{r}^{*}(G * \mathbb{Z})$ into $C_{r}^{*}(G)^{\mathcal{U}}$ which requires estimating the operator norm on all of $\mathbb{C}(G * \mathbb{Z})$ simultaneously. This is precisely why removing the rapid decay assumption is apriori difficult.

# Appendix A. Quantitative version of Wenyuan Yang's admissible path lemma 

The aim of this section is to prove a quantitative version of W. Yang's admissible path lemma [68, Corollary 3.4], which applies to our setting. For our purposes, we will take a fixed action on a hyperbolic space but vary the loxodromic element and thus the quasi-geodesic constants $\lambda$. So throughout, we track dependence on $\lambda$. The following quantitative version of the Morse lemma is present in [29, Section 5.2]; see [62, Theorem 1.1]) for an explicit polynomial.
Lemma A.1. [Quantitative Morse Lemma] Let $X$ be a $\delta$-hyperbolic space, and let $\gamma$ be a $(\lambda, 0)$ -quasi-geodesic. Let $\sigma$ be a geodesic with the same endpoints as $\gamma$. Then $\gamma$ is contained in a $Q_{1}(\lambda)$ neighborhood of $\sigma$ with $Q_{1}$ a quadratic polynomial (which depends on $\delta$ ).

We continue with some notation. Let $(G, S) \curvearrowright X$ be a group $G$ with a finite generating set $S$ acting acylindrically on a $\delta$-hyperbolic space $X$. Fix an origin $o \in X$. Let $g \in G$ be a loxodromic element. Let $\tau(g)=\lim _{n} \frac{d\left(g^{n} o, o\right)}{n}$ denote the stable length of $g$. We observe that $\tau(g)$ is independent of the choice of base point and is stable under conjugation. Let $[g]$ denote the displacement (or translation length) of $g$, defined by

$$
[g]=\inf _{x \in X} d(g x, x)
$$

This infimum is in fact achieved at some point $x_{0} \in X$. We let $L_{g}=\cup_{n \in \mathbb{Z}}\left[g^{n} x_{0}, g^{n+1} x_{0}\right]$. Let $\gamma=\cup_{n \in \mathbb{Z}}\left[g^{n} o, g^{n+1} o\right]$ be the axis of $g$ going through $o$. Let $\lambda=\frac{d(g o, o)}{\tau(g)}$ so that $\gamma$ is a $(\lambda, 0)$-quasiaxis; i.e., if $m<n$ are integers then

$$
\ell(\gamma)=\sum_{i=m}^{n-1} d\left(g^{i} o, g^{i+1} o\right) \leq \lambda d\left(\gamma^{-}, \gamma^{+}\right)=\lambda d\left(g^{n-m} o, o\right)
$$

Note that clearly $[g] \leq d(g o, o)=\tau(g) \lambda$. Let $E(g)$ denote the maximal elementary (i.e., virtually cyclic) subgroup of $G$ containing $g$. For sets $Y, Z \subset X$, let $\pi_{Y}(Z)$ denote the projection of $Z$ onto $Y$. More precisely, $y \in \pi_{Y}(Z)$ if and only if $y \in Y$ and there exists $z \in Z$ such that $d(y, z)=$ $\min \left\{d\left(y^{\prime}, z\right): y^{\prime} \in Y\right\}$. For a set $Y \subset X$ let $\|Y\|$ denote its diameter; i.e., the smallest real number such that $d\left(y, y^{\prime}\right) \leq\|Y\|$ for all $y, y^{\prime} \in Y$.

The following is due to Delzant. We note that the constant $D_{0}$ below depends only on the action $G \curvearrowright X$.

Proposition A.2. ( [21, Proposition 5]) Let $G \curvearrowright X$ be an acylindrical action on a hyperbolic space and let $g \in G$ be a loxodromic element (i.e. a hyperbolic isometry). Then for all $h \notin E(g)$,

$$
\left\|\pi_{L_{g}}\left(h L_{g}\right)\right\| \leq D_{0}(1+[g])
$$

The following lemma is the quantitative version of [64, Lemma 2.23].
Lemma A. 3 (Quantitative Bounded Projection). There is a quadratic $Q_{2}$ such that whenever a loxodromic element $g$ and a point $x \in X$ gives a $(\lambda, 0)$-quasi-axis $\gamma=\cup_{n \in \mathbb{Z}}\left[g^{n} x, g^{n+1} x\right]$ and $h \notin E(g)$, then

$$
\left\|\pi_{\gamma}(h \gamma)\right\| \leq Q_{2}(\lambda)(1+[g])
$$

Proof. The quasi-axes $\gamma$ and $L_{g}$ both converge to the same points on the Gromov boundary of $X$. We may, therefore, apply the quantitative Morse lemma to transfer the inequality from Proposition A. 2 to $\gamma$, up to a quadratic in $\lambda$.

The following theorem, the main theorem of this section, is essentially a reproduction of [68, Corollary 3.4] but where we have tracked all of the constants and dependencies to verify they grow polynomially.

Theorem A. 4 (Quantitative Admissible Path Theorem). Let $(G, S) \curvearrowright X$ be a group $G$ with a finite generating set $S$ acting acylindrically on a $\delta$-hyperbolic space $X$. Fix a constant $C>0$. There is a degree 6 polynomial $P$ (depending on $G, S, X, \delta, C$ ) such that if $g$ is loxodromic with $\tau(g)=C$, then for all group elements $h_{1}, \ldots, h_{m} \notin E(g)$ such that $\left|h_{i}\right|_{S} \leq|g|_{S}$, the product $h_{1} g^{n_{1}} h_{2} g^{n_{2}} \cdots h_{m} g^{n_{m}} \neq e$ whenever $\left|n_{i}\right| \geq P\left(|g|_{S}\right)$ for all $1 \leq i \leq m$ (with $n_{m}$ also being allowed to equal 0 ).

Proof. Set $\lambda=\frac{d(g o, o)}{\tau(g)}$. Let $\mathcal{L}$ be the collection of $(\lambda, 0)$-quasi-geodesics in $X$; in particular, $\mathcal{L}$ includes all geodesics since (without loss of generality) $\lambda \geq 1$. Let $\mathbb{X}$ be defined by $\mathbb{X}=$ $\left\{\cup_{n=k}^{\ell}\left[h g^{n}, 0, h g^{n+1} o\right]: h \notin E(g)\right\}$ and note that $\mathbb{X} \subset \mathcal{L}$. By Lemma A. 1 and [9, Section 3], we have that $\mathbb{X}$ is $(\mu, \varepsilon)$-contracting with respect to $\mathcal{L}$ where $\mu, \varepsilon$ are uniformly bounded above by a quadratic $Q_{3}(\lambda)$. That is, whenever $q \in \mathcal{L}$ and $p \in \mathbb{X}$ such that $d(q, p) \geq Q_{3}(\lambda)$ then $\left\|\pi_{p}(q)\right\|<Q_{3}(\lambda)$. (In the notation of [68], $\mu\left(\lambda^{\prime}, c^{\prime}\right), \varepsilon\left(\lambda^{\prime}, c^{\prime}\right) \leq Q_{3}(\lambda)$ for all $\left.\lambda^{\prime}, c^{\prime} \in \mathbb{R}\right)$

We now obtain that for each $p \in \mathbb{X}, p$ is $\sigma$-quasiconvex where $\sigma(U)=\frac{3}{2} Q_{3}(\lambda)+2 U$. Indeed, let $q$ be a geodesic in $X$ such that its endpoints $q^{+}$and $q^{-}$are in the $U$-neighborhood $N_{U}(p)$ of $p$. Since $p$ is $(\mu, \varepsilon)$-contracting, either $d(q, p)<\mu$ (and we are done) or $\left\|\pi_{p}(q)\right\|<\varepsilon$. In particular, we have $d\left(q^{+}, q^{-}\right) \leq \varepsilon+2 U$. Since $q$ is a geodesic, for any $x \in q$ we have $d\left(q^{+}, x\right)+d\left(q^{-}, x\right)=d\left(q^{+}, q^{-}\right)$. Therefore without loss of generality $d\left(q^{+}, x\right) \leq \varepsilon / 2+U$, implying that $d\left(x, \pi_{p}(x)\right)<2 U+\frac{3}{2} \varepsilon$. Thus $q \subset N_{\sigma(U)}(p)$.

By Lemma A.3, if $p, p^{\prime} \in \mathbb{X}$ are quasi-geodesics corresponding to $h, h^{\prime}$ in different left cosets of $E(g)$, then $p, p^{\prime}$ have bounded projection $T$ where $T=Q_{2}(\lambda)(1+[g])=O\left(\lambda^{3}\right)$ since $[g] \leq$ $d(g o, o)=\tau(g) \lambda$ (and the stable length $\tau(g)$ is fixed). We note that in [68], the symbol $\tau$ is used for bounded projection but we have already used $\tau$ for stable length. By [68, Lemma 2.7], $p, p^{\prime}$ also have $\nu$-bounded intersection where $\nu(U)=2 U+O\left(\lambda^{3}\right)$.

Now let $n_{1}, \ldots, n_{k}$ be integers and consider the path

$$
\begin{aligned}
P= & {\left[o, h_{1} o\right] \cup\left[h_{1} o, h_{1} g o\right] \cup \ldots \cup\left[h_{1} g^{n_{1}-1} o, h_{1} g^{n_{1}} o\right] \cup\left[h_{1} g^{n_{1}} o, h_{1}, g^{n_{1}} h_{2} o\right] \cup \ldots } \\
& \ldots \cup\left[h_{1} g^{n_{1}} \cdots h_{k} g^{n_{k}-1} o, h_{1} g^{n_{1}} \cdots h_{m} g^{n_{m}} o\right],
\end{aligned}
$$

and set

$$
\begin{aligned}
q_{1} & =\left[o, h_{1} o\right] \\
q_{2} & =\left[h_{1} g^{n_{1}} o, h_{1} g^{n_{1}} g h_{2} o\right] \\
q_{3}, \ldots, q_{m} & =\ldots \\
p_{1} & =\left[h_{1} o, h_{1} g^{\operatorname{sgn}\left(n_{1}\right)} o\right] \cup \ldots \cup\left[h_{1} g^{n_{1}-\operatorname{sgn}\left(n_{1}\right)} o, h_{1} g^{n_{1}} o\right] \\
p_{2} & =\left[h_{1} g^{n_{1}} h_{2} o, h_{1} g^{n_{1}} h_{2} g^{\operatorname{sgn}\left(n_{2}\right)} o\right] \cup \ldots \cup\left[h_{1} g^{n_{1}} h_{2} g^{n_{2}-\operatorname{sgn}\left(n_{2}\right)} o, h_{1} g^{n_{1}} h_{2} g^{n_{2}} o\right] \\
p_{3}, \ldots, p_{m} & =\ldots
\end{aligned}
$$

$P$ is a path from $o$ to $h_{1} g^{n_{1}} h_{2} g^{n_{2}} \cdots h_{m} g^{n_{m}} o$ in $X$. We note that each $p_{i}$ is a $(\lambda, 0)$-quasi-geodesic in $\mathbb{X}$ (and thus has two endpoints in some $p^{\prime} \in \mathbb{X}$ ), each $p_{i}$ has length at least $\tau(g)\left|n_{i}\right|$, each $q_{i}$ has $C^{\prime}|g|_{S}$-bounded projection to $p_{i}$ and $p_{i-1}$ (since $q_{i}$ is a geodesic of length at most $\left.C^{\prime}|h|_{S} \leq C^{\prime}|g|_{S}\right.$ where $C^{\prime}=\max _{k \in S} d(k o, o)$; note that $C^{\prime}$ is a constant dependent only on the group action and the choice of generating set), and any two $p_{i}, p_{i+1}$ have $\nu$-bounded intersection since each $h_{i} \notin E(g)$ so $p_{i}, p_{i+1}$ lie in different quasi-axes of $g$. We note that $\lambda=\tau(g) d(g o, o) \leq \tau(g) C^{\prime}|g|_{S}$ so that $\lambda=O\left(|g|_{S}\right)$.

We are now ready to analyze the constants in the proof of [68, Proposition 3.3]. We have $c=0$ everywhere.

$$
C_{\lambda, 0}=\lambda(\mu(\lambda, 0)+\epsilon(\lambda, 0)+C^{\prime}|g|_{S})
$$

$$
\begin{aligned}
= & O\left(|g|_{S}^{3}\right) \\
& B_{\lambda, 0}=2 \varepsilon(1,0)+2 \mu(1,0)+\nu(\mu(1,0)+\sigma(0))+|g|_{S} \\
= & O\left(|g|^{2}\right) \\
R= & \max \left(C^{\prime}|g|_{S}+2 \varepsilon(1,0)+4 \mu(1,0)+1\right. \\
& \mu(1,0)+5 \varepsilon(1,0)+B_{\lambda, 0}+1) \\
= & O\left(|g|_{S}^{2}\right) \\
& \Lambda=\lambda(6 R+1) \\
= & O\left(|g|_{S}^{3}\right) \\
D= & \max \left(\mu(1,0)+\varepsilon(1,0)+C^{\prime}|g|_{S}+C_{\lambda, 0}\right. \\
& 2 T+3 \varepsilon(1,0)+6 \mu(1,0) \\
& \left.\Lambda(R+\sigma(\mu(1,0))\right) \\
& 13 \varepsilon(1,0)+6 \mu(1,0)+2 B_{\lambda, 0}\right) \\
= & O\left(|g|_{S}^{5}\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

Now, if we choose all of the $n_{i}$ so that $\left|n_{i}\right|$ are larger than $\lambda D=O\left(|g|_{S}^{6}\right)$, we can apply [68, Corollary 3.4] to obtain that our path $P$ is a $(\Lambda, 0)$-quasi-geodesic. In particular, $P$ is nontrivial and so it must be that $h_{1} g^{n_{1}} h_{2} g^{n_{2}} \cdots h_{m} g^{n_{m}} \neq e$. (Note that in the case $n_{m}=0$, we can still apply [68, Corollary 3.4].) This finishes the proof.

abstract:
We prove that for every $n\geq 2$, the reduced group $C^*$-algebras of the
countable free groups $C^*_r(\mathbb{F}_n)$ have strict comparison. Our method
works in a general setting: for $G$ in a large family of non-amenable groups,
including hyperbolic groups, free products, mapping class groups, right-angled
Artin groups etc., we have $C^*_r(G)$ have strict comparison. This work also
has several applications in the theory of $C^*$-algebras including: resolving
Leonel Robert's selflessness problem for $C^*_r(G)$; uniqueness of embeddings
of the Jiang-Su algebra $\mathcal{Z}$ up to approximate unitary equivalence
into $C^*_r(G)$; full computations of the Cuntz semigroup of $C^*_r(G)$ and
future directions in the $C^*$-classification program.
